awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Data-Driven Study of Attacks on Cyber-Physical Infrastructure Supporting Large Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses security attacks that: (i) masquerade as failures and (ii) are delivered via self-learning malware that monitors the target system and launches the attack at a time and system location to have a maximal impact, by injecting a strategic failure. The target systems are cyber-physical systems (CPS) that manage or control large computing enterprises (e.g., the cooling or power distribution of high-performance system or cloud infrastructure). In this scenario, the vulnerability of the cyber-physical system acts as a weak point that lowers the security barrier of an otherwise well-protected system. This project addresses a full range of issues, including: (i) design of self-learning malware; (ii) launch vectors for failure injection attacks; and (iii) mitigation and defense against such attacks. The research draws on data from a cyber-physical system that supports the cooling of the Blue Waters supercomputing system at the University of Illinois.

The intellectual merit of this work lies in: (i) Development of scientifically sound methods to jointly study reliability failures of, and malicious attacks on, a cyber-physical system infrastructure that provides critical services for the uninterruptible operation of a large computing infrastructure. Possible advances in cyber-attacks in the context of indirectness, automation (driven by self-learning and adaptive malware), and reduced barriers to unauthorized entry to the system are considered; (ii) Study of feasibility of deploying attacks through self-learning malware (inserted into the auxiliary CPS), which takes advantage of a low-security barrier. In cyber-physical systems, the real-time control sequences rely on online measurements from the sensors distributed across the system. By monitoring those measurements one can build smart malware that is able to learn (interpret) the system state and then trigger an attack sequence at an opportune time; (iii) Develop attack mitigation methods that can be integrated with an existing intrusion detection system and combined with the monitoring from the cyber and physical layers of the tenant system; (iv) Validation of the mitigation strategies using a data-driven simulation testbed that emulates the cyber-physical system behavior and enables experimentation with different attack scenarios. While we focus on a large computing infrastructure, the problem has broader implications, e.g., the proliferation of "Internet of Things" devices creates an environment for attackers to exploit vulnerabilities in such entities as a stepping stone for launching attacks against highly-valuable assets. In the broader context of cyber security, this project aims to identify potential advances in threats by demonstrating the feasibility of masquerading a security problem as a reliability failure. Demonstrating a proof-of-concept on a potential threat and presenting an effective mitigation method will promote the development of detection and mitigation techniques against new threats.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The growing sophistication of cyber-physical systems (CPS), while enabling breakthroughs in different application domains, also brings new vulnerabilities that malicious actors can exploit. In this research, we consider indirect security attacks that take advantage of the relatively weak security of the CPS as a stepping stone toward compromising the target system. Unlike the known CPS attacks, our advanced attack scenario distinguishes itself by: (i) masquerading itself as an accidental failure by inducing abnormalities (failures) in the CPS whose impact propagates to the target-dependent system (e.g., a large computing infrastructure in our study) and (ii) minimizing the risk of exposure and detection by introducing self-learning features to the malware deployed in the CPS to learn and execute the attack scenario based on the events corresponding to the behavior of the CPS under regular operations. We also devise methods to preemptively detect such malicious attacks, which is an important step toward developing mitigation strategies. Finally, we generalize the threat model to capture (i) purposeful manipulation of information/data available via online monitoring of a cyber-physical system and (ii) attacks that combine both reliability and security features of the CPS and computing enterprise. Specifically, we consider a new attack type, ML-driven malware, where malicious logic:

(i)  embeds machine learning models to probe the target system for inferring actionable intelligence, e.g., system configuration or operational patterns

(ii)  customizes the attack payload to determine the most suitable time for executing the payload to maximize the negative impact on the target system.

Such an ML-driven malware mimics the thought process of a human attacker and hence, allows encoding the malicious intention into the ML model and generalizing the attack to an extended range of targets. Conceptually, ML-driven malware can be considered a skeleton with a structure of the attack strategy/payload with the details to be configured. Upon deployment inside the target system, the skeleton is fleshed out with the details to determine "what, when, and how" to attack based on the operational data from the target system. We demonstrate the feasibility of self-learning malware in three different use cases:

Case 1: Use of Leaked Control Data to Compromise Robotic Applications - Raven-II-based Surgical Robots

Raven-II is driven by the Robot Operating System (ROS), an open-source framework widely deployed across various robotic applications. However, ROS contains vulnerabilities that can leak data (e.g., robot state) transmitted within the application. Those data can become the basis for smart malware to learn about the system behavior and use this information to decide when to trigger an attack. We exploited ROS vulnerabilities and implemented smart malware that tracks the movement of the robot's arms and triggers the attack payload when the robot is in a critical state of a surgical procedure. Our malware runs outside the robotic application's physical components, making the malware learning process invisible to security monitoring systems. After demonstrating the security threats, we present methods (i.e., a safety module) to protect the robotic system against the identified risk.

Case 2: Availability Attacks against High-Performance Computing Systems through Alteration of Environmental Control - Blue Waters HPC System

The target system we focus on is a CPS that manages and controls the cooling system for a large computing enterprise (i.e., the Blue Waters supercomputer operated by the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at UIUC). We address a range of issues, including the self-learning malware's construction and the attack's launch. Provided with real CPS data, our malware inferred several unique attack strategies which disrupt the cooling system while the attack masquerades as an accidental CPS failure. We validated the attacks in a data-driven CPS simulator developed as part of this study.

Case 3: Data Breach Attacks - Smart Malware-Driven Stealthy Data Exfiltration at Large Computing Enterprise

We demonstrate our smart data-driven malware in the context of data breach attacks at large computing enterprises. Our malware consists of two machine learning modules: (i) the forecast module to predict patterns of normal network activities in the victim system and (ii) the exfiltration module to derive the best exfiltration action given the forecast. This advanced threat can challenge current protection methods that look for abnormal behavior in systems. If such a threat becomes a reality, an intelligent malware can spread itself automatically across multiple victims (like worms and viruses) and challenge the operators, as (i) the threat customization will be automatically driven by the victim's local data, and (ii) the intelligence will accumulate as the malware morphs and passes through multiple victims. Our experimental findings reveal a need to proactively investigate new detection and mitigation methods that target such new threats.

The results from this research have been published in top-tier conferences and included as a book chapter in "Game Theory and Machine Learning for Cyber Security," C. A. Kamhoua, C. D. Kiekintveld, F. Fang, Q. Zhu, Eds., John Wiley & Sons, 2021.
